record.desc: Extreme: Rigid control of civilian movement
Extreme: All facets of daily life rigidly controlled
Extreme: Severe punishments for petty infractions
Pre-Industrial: Bronze age to Middle ages

Possible dangers or other internal restrictions may place visitors at risk. Travellers should avoid this area."

record.desc: Darrian Confederation Naval with Marine contingent
Independant world Naval, Marine and Army
Aslan Tlaukhu Naval and Clan Naval

table.desc: Galactic's color map for links and others

record.desc: Blue: 7,500 to 11,000 Kelvin. Hydrogen lines at max. for A0.
Blue: 11,000 to 25,000 Kelvin. Neutral helium lines in absorption.
"Carbon" stars - group class for Asymptotic Giant Branch (AGB) stars. Superceded class.
Blue-White: 6,000 to 7,500 Kelvin. Metallic lines in record.
Yellow-White: 5,000 to 6,000 Kelvin. Solar-type record (netral metallic atoms and ions).
Red-Orange: 3,500 to 5,000 Kelvin. Weak blue continuum, metallic lines dominate.
Red: 3,500 (or less) Kelvin. Molecular bands of titanium oxide noticable.
Asymptotic Giant Branch (AGB) type M "carbon" star.
Blue: 25,000 (or more) Kelvin. Singly ionised helium lines in emission and absorption. Strong ultraviolet continuum.
Asymptotic Giant Branch (AGB) type K "carbon" star.
Asymptotic Giant Branch (AGB) type M "iron" star.
Tauri stars. Bright, irregular, variable stars within interstellar clouds (normally).
Wolf-Rayet stars (type O) with broad emission lines for hydrogen and ionised helium, carbon, nitrogen and oxygen (very few absorption lines).
Abnormally strong metallic lines (not hydrogen or helium) for given spectral type.
Broad (nebulous) absorption lines due to fast rotation.
Very broad absorption lines due to very fast rotation.
Nebula spectrum merged with the star's spectrum.
Unspecified peculiarity (except with type A, where it denotes extremely strong metal lines).
Very narrow (sharp) lines in emission or absorption.
Shell star (B to F main sequence with emission lines from a shell of gas).
Weak lines, suggesting an ancient "metal-poor" star.
